<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 348, 293]]<|/det|>
## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 268, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Non-calculator  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 301, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
February/March 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 325, 905, 340]]<|/det|>
2 hours  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 560]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- Calculators must not be used in this paper.- You must show all necessary working clearly.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 603]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 730, 636]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 107, 475, 126]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[601, 101, 787, 122]]<|/det|>
\((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 152, 584, 170]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[604, 152, 675, 170]]<|/det|>
\(A = \pi r l\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 199, 680, 217]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[604, 199, 685, 217]]<|/det|>
\(A = 4\pi r^2\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 246, 680, 268]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V,\) of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[604, 243, 680, 269]]<|/det|>
\(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 297, 680, 316]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V,\) of sphere of radius \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[604, 292, 685, 316]]<|/det|>
\(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 344, 232, 362]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 344, 655, 363]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(a x^{2} + b x + c = 0\),

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 364, 556, 396]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 440, 225, 458]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 432, 907, 470]]<|/det|>
\((a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n},\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 477, 771, 515]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 546, 217, 562]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 545, 678, 586]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{l}{u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d}\\ {S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\left\{2a + (n - 1)d\right\}} \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 623, 215, 640]]<|/det|>
Geometric series

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 622, 567, 700]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{l}{u_{n} = a r^{n - 1}}\\ {S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r}\quad (r\neq 1)}\\ {S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r}\quad (|r|< 1)} \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 733, 156, 750]]<|/det|>
Identities

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 730, 544, 784]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{l}\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\\ \sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\\ \csc^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 821, 242, 839]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 816, 581, 895]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{array}{l}\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\\ a^2 = b^2 + c^2 - 2bc\cos A\\ \Delta = \frac{1}{2} ab\sin C \end{array}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[331, 71, 667, 89]]<|/det|>
Calculators must **not** be used in this paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 102, 97, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 101, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graphs of \(y = 4|x - 1|\) and \(y = \left|3x + 2\right|\), stating the intercepts with the axes.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 117, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[141, 144, 833, 497]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 515, 475, 535]]<|/det|>
Solve the inequality \(4|x - 1| \leqslant |3x + 2|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 515, 920, 534]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 69, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 87, 876, 313]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 332, 685, 352]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = a\cos bx + c\) for \(- 180^{\circ}\leqslant x\leqslant 180^{\circ}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 348, 411, 367]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 380, 346, 399]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 381, 918, 400]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 535, 92, 553]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 535, 405, 554]]<|/det|>
The point \(A\) has coordinates \((- 3, 6)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 549, 405, 570]]<|/det|>
The point \(B\) has coordinates \((7, - 8)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 580, 737, 600]]<|/det|>
Given that the line \(AB\) is the diameter of a circle, find the equation of the circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 581, 918, 600]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 811, 109]]<|/det|>
The polynomial p is given by \(\mathrm{p}(x) = a^{2}x^{3} + 2ax^{2} + ax + 2\), where \(a\) is a positive integer. It is given that \(2x + 1\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 121, 146, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 121, 311, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 494, 146, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 494, 326, 512]]<|/det|>
Hence factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 494, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 695, 144, 714]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 695, 665, 714]]<|/det|>
Hence show that the equation \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 0\) has only one real root.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 694, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 94, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 144, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 75, 767, 97]]<|/det|>
Write \(2x^{2} - 2x + 3\) in the form \(a\big(x + b\big)^{2} + c\) , where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 75, 918, 94]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 262, 531, 285]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{f}(x) = 2x^{2} - 2x + 3,\) for \(x\leqslant p\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 295, 146, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 295, 638, 316]]<|/det|>
Write down the greatest value of \(p\) for which f has an inverse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 295, 918, 314]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 419, 143, 437]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 419, 532, 439]]<|/det|>
Using this value of \(p\), write down the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 419, 920, 438]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 559, 146, 578]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 559, 541, 579]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 559, 920, 578]]<|/det|>

<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 75, 524, 102]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\tan \theta = \frac{\sqrt{5}}{5}\) and \(180^{\circ}< \theta < 360^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 146, 131]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 344, 131]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 112, 920, 131]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 146, 318]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 454, 405, 472]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\sec \theta + \cot \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 697, 510]]<|/det|>
Give your answer in the form \(\frac{a + b\sqrt{c}}{\sqrt{5}}\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 428, 920, 472]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y = \frac{5}{x + 1} + 2\) and part of the line \(y = 2x + 1\) intersecting at the point \(A\).

<label>(a)</label>

<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 485, 89]]<|/det|>
The first term of a geometric progression is 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 576, 106]]<|/det|>
This geometric progression has a positive common ratio \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 532, 135]]<|/det|>
The first term of an arithmetic progression is also 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 133, 625, 151]]<|/det|>
This arithmetic progression has a negative common difference \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 845, 198]]<|/det|>
The second term of the geometric progression is the same as the fourth term of the arithmetic progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 195, 917, 214]]<|/det|>
The third term of the geometric progression is the same as the sixth term of the arithmetic progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 227, 144, 244]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 227, 364, 244]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(r\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 227, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 81, 104, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 78, 467, 101]]<|/det|>
The point \(P\) lies on the curve \(y = \left(5x + 2\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 97, 326, 116]]<|/det|>
The \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) is 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 112, 695, 133]]<|/det|>
The normal to the curve at \(P\) intersects the line \(x + y = 11\) at the point \(Q\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 127, 626, 147]]<|/det|>
The point \(R\) is the reflection of \(Q\) in the tangent to the curve at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 159, 322, 178]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 160, 920, 179]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 453, 89]]<|/det|>
Continuation of working space for Question 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 102, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 88, 839, 314]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 333, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
In the diagram, \(\overrightarrow{OA} = \mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{OB} = \mathbf{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
The point \(M\) is the midpoint of \(OB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 370, 395, 392]]<|/det|>
The point \(N\) is such that \(\overrightarrow{ON} = 3\overrightarrow{NA}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 390, 472, 411]]<|/det|>
The lines \(BN\) and \(AM\) intersect at the point \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 408, 395, 429]]<|/det|>
\(\overrightarrow{BX} = \lambda \overrightarrow{BN}\), where \(\lambda\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 427, 395, 448]]<|/det|>
\(\overrightarrow{MX} = \mu \overrightarrow{MA}\), where \(\mu\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 460, 144, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 460, 410, 479]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{OX}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}\), \(\mathbf{b}\) and \(\lambda\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 460, 910, 479]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 77, 146, 95]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 77, 411, 96]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{OX}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 77, 920, 95]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 497, 144, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 497, 420, 515]]<|/det|>
Hence find the values of \(\lambda\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 497, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
